job_title: Medical Assistant in New York, NY
pros: You learn a lot about the clinical aspect of the medical field. Opportunity to learn to work with doctors and patients. Opportunity to help those in need of help in the community
cons: You are expected to do a lot, and there is a lack of support for clinical staff. You get yelled at by patients, doctors and other staff for not meeting their demand but your pay doesn't compensate for all the stress you have to deal with.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: I was lucky to have really hardworking coworkers. Learned a lot about the job and new skills.
cons: High turnover rate. Extremely overworked staff. Blame game 24/7. Management does not want employees to grow and succeed. Reward lazy employees but throw hardworkers under the bus. Technology is too outdated. Claims to care about patients yet they do not do anything to make things more accessible and convenient for members in the community.

job_title: IT Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Team is composed of good people who work hard and get tasks done, you will make great friends working here Many learning opportunities
cons: Wage is well below market average depending on your position. One, singular, toxic coworker can ruin the entire experience. Anyone who has been here in the past 10 years on the team knows exactly who the person is, unfortunately you can't steer clear of this coworker and everything you do will be under a microscope and you will be ridiculed, demeaned, and berated.

review_title: One for all and all for one

job_title: Chief Executive Officer (CEO) in New York, NY
pros: Wonderful mission. Committed and collaborative staff. Recognized nationally for high clinical quality.
cons: Like many mission-driven health centers, CBWCHC wrestles with financial constraints and regulatory uncertainties.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Flushing, NY
pros:
I been working at CBW for almost 2 years. Choice/vacation time is good compare to other companies but no actual holidays off (e.g. for xmas they take away vacation time) 

The work place is mainly consist of two type of employees (excluding providers and nurses). 
1. Old timers who can't find a job anywhere else and are here to stay till their retirement.
2.  And new grads who needs experience. 

This is a good place if you plan on balancing work/school life.
cons:
There are so many downsides to working for CBWCHC. I will just list a few 
 
1. Managers like to blame their own team/staff for shortcomings and take credit for projects. 

2. There is minimal vertical growth and the salary is ridiculously low (even for a "nonprofit").  

3. CBW have a lot of moochers.  There are people that spent 2+ HOURS on the work phone gossiping  on a daily basis. They barely get any work done because if they are not on the phone gossiping, they are walking around looking for people to talk to. 

4. Because the salary is so low, the turnover rate is high. You would never have a full team. If you are "covering" a task while they are "hiring", its basically your task forever.

Do not work for cbw unless you are desperate. Anyone who stays in cbw for more than 2.5 years just can't find a job elsewhere. All the smart people leave and the team gets stuck with all the old and lazy members.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: The health center is very mission driven, and staff believe and incorporate this mission driven mindset everyday. There is lots of opportunities to learn and develop skills, and work focuses on serving and working with the community in mind. Working at the health center is especially beneficial to those just starting their careers and want exposure to the non-profit, community driven health sector. There is a mix between young professionals starting out for skill development, and long tenured staff who appreciate the easy going work environment and mission driven values. It provides endless opportunities to learn, serve a good cause, and grow as a professional. Executive and senior staff are high quality and experienced.
cons: Very low salary, can be hard to sustain off of especially in a place like New York City. Due to the small size of the organization, it is also hard to advance to higher positions in the organization. There is a high turnover of staff, and often support for projects is lacking as it can be very burdensome for staff to put on multiple hats.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Flushing, NY
pros: Good benefits if you stay long term, PTO is better than the national average. Good place to use as a training camp before moving onto somewhere better.
cons: Promotions and raises are given to friends, relatives, and favorites, not based on who is actually qualified and deserving of them (for Flushing site). This leads to poor management and leadership, which then leads to high turnover rate. The place is chronically understaffed because people keep leaving and current staff ends up doing two-person jobs with already embarrassingly low pay. Management can get desperate by hiring underqualified candidates and lets them go soon after because of underperformance. Of course the employees who are not friends/relatives/favorites take the fall for failures and mistakes because someone needs to be blamed.

review_title: Not a good place to work for if you are looking to grow
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Schedule is flexible and staff are very friendly. Since it's a non-profit, the working environment is lay-back and co-workers are generally supportive. The Center is well connected with local agencies and hospitals, so there are opportunities to make connection with people outside of the organization.
cons: The pay is horrible. Very low considering NYC living standard. Benefits aren't that great either. The worst part is that there's no room to grow for a junior person. Most of senior staff are too comfortable to move. People stuck in the middle have no room to advance, hence people in the bottom either stay in the bottom forever or leave. The turn-over rate for junior staff is extremely high.

review_title: Review by staff with two-year work experience at CBWCHC
job_title: in New York, NY
pros: Good benefits (including health plus dental insurance and paid vacation for full-time workers), overall friendly environment, good for transition between school and work in healthcare for recent college graduates
cons: Exclusive environment if you don't understand Cantonese (for the Chinatown site) but you are Asian (e.g. if you are Mandarin-speaking only or Korean) since 90% of staff speak Cantonese in private. Pay and workload are very disproportional, you will most likely be underpaid.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Flushing, NY
pros: Nice and good medical staff for newbies. Wonderful doctors to work with. Flexible schedule. Job duties are simple and easy. Good benefit compared to other private sector
cons: Unprofessional management - people in management level are all relatives with no education background. Overall, upper level don't value their good employees, but cover their "relatives" or "church friends". Yearly raise percentage based on favoritism.

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: Good people, good salary, flexible hours, work at your own pace. Good place to develop cultural competency as it serves primarily low-income Asian populations.
cons: Politics and bureaucracy can sometimes stifle creativity and motivation. Promotions are rare and raises limited. Not sure if hard work and long hours are rewarded with better pay.

review_title: Profits oriented at a Community Health Center
job_title: Physician in New York, NY
pros:
1. Lay back environment for some.  "Work less, but make a decent living" - was a new strategy introduced per lower management.
2. Reasonable benefits.
3. For those who are friends and / or relatives and / or the favorites of the management / administrators - great places to work.
cons:
1. The hard working person will continue to work harder for the survivals.
2. High turn over rate means a lot to some people.
3. Voices may not be heard by the senior management as the lower manageement does the filtering, so all departments look great with superb perfomance.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
Benefits - there’s employer contribution of 6% of your annual salary towards your 403B plus you can electively defer your pretax income as well. You get 9 paid holidays, sick days, personal days and personal time off. All those PTO comes out from a holiday bank called “choice time.” Medical and dental coverage are provided. Life insurance is offered by company. It’s valued at double your annual salary. So if you make 40K, the life insurance payout will be 80K.

Doctors - one of the best team I have worked with. For that reason and the mission were the main reason I had stayed this long
cons:
Great nonprofit organization with a great mission however this place is run by old school minded management that’s been working here more than 15-20 years. Depending which department you work for- you may feel miserable. As much as I love working with most of my coworkers, very often do I feel common sense is not that common. It’s very stressful working with a team of incompetent and poorly spoken English staff.


Hours - Work hours are 70 hours every two weeks however some supervisor will schedule you below your agreed contract hours and then tap into your PTO. Like wtf? It’s bad enough that It’s non-profit pay but you still under schedule staff to budget cost. You will feel cheated sometimes to have to use your own vacation time because supervisor decides budget cost.

Annual increment is NOT based on work performance but rather how well you are favored by your supervisor. It leaves staff who has excellent attendance and works hard to question their loyalty. What incentive does any staff have if you promote someone who has lousy work ethics compared to someone who’s giving their 100%?

review_title: Good company with structure and system
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Strong leadership; C suite with long tenure with the company.  Company continues to grow.  Most managers are competent.  Great learning opportunities at all positions.
cons: Salary is relatively low as nonprofit; but benefit package is OK.  Many managers are inside promoted, lacking real managerial skills.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
Great for job experience, and exposure to gain many job skills.
Nothing more.
cons:
Way too many to list!!

RIDICULOUSLY LOW PAY!! Don't expect a raise or bother asking for one (never received a performance review either). Raises are given only to the favorites, and those who've been around for 10+ years. Very few will get 3%, while the rest get NOTHING.

Forced to use your own accrued PTO for every time the office is closed (Yes, that includes: Christmas, New Years, Memorial Day, July 4th, etc.) Also, doesn't seem like they follow the NY Paid Family Leave rules either, I've been told to use PTO for my own doctors appointments (pretty sure this is against the law).

Expect to come in early, and stay late, NO OVERTIME, and then be scolded for asking to leave 3 hrs early on Friday because you worked an extra 3 hours on Wednesday.

Good at what you do? Here's 20 more things for you to handle. Don't mess any of it up either or get ripped a new one. Keep in mind.. NO extra pay! 
"You should be glad you were given this opportunity." - CBWCHC Executive

SUPER POLITICAL, to the point where departments will almost intentionally sabotage the work of an another. Executives who try to manipulate staff, gossip, spread stories, then pass it off as "getting to know each other".

review_title: this is a training center. not a health center.
